reviews.review_text: Do you want one of the most accurate simulations of wrestling money can buy?  Do you want (mostly) outstanding graphics and smooth gameplay?  Do you want a relatively robust amount of unlocks customization options?  Do you want a ridiculous (and I mean ridiculous) roster size?  Do you want to play a plethora of matches from wrestling history?  Do you want a satisfying amount of well-made community content?  Do you want to talk about Tyler Breeze?    This is the game for you    Are you like me and more or less simply want a career mode akin to the old SvR games, with a never ending cycle, branching paths and voice acting?  Do you want a large variety of match types, again akin to the SvR games?    Nooooope     Basically If all you want is a great wrestling sim with plenty of unlocks and historical matches, look no further. You will get hours of fun from this game. But if you want a satisfying career mode or unique match types, you will be often frustrated by this game. The career mode is repetetive and dull and you CAN'T use your character in any mode other than career, even after you retire. And beyond 2k showcase, don't expect to see buried alive matches and really any niche match types.    6.5/10 for me, 9/10 if my negatives don't matter to you

Short version: This is no different to last year. The only change is now you have a set amount of reversals (that you regain over time) to avoid the ridiculous amont of reversals of yesteryear. Unless you REALLY love Showcase or somehow weren't bored of the Career or Universe mode's repetition, you won't miss this. It's probably better than what THQ would still be producing, but 2K are just like WWE - phoning it in now they have no competition. Why try?  Long version:  Exactly as I said in my review of last year's game, there are moments of huge potential hidden in here.  The movement is so fluid nowadays that things look a notch more realistic (like playing a tag match as The Outsiders, and Hall slips out of a move and pushes the guy in your direction as you run up and deliver Nash's Big Boot finisher, beautiful).  The tech is advanced enough to have physics for satisfying impacts on weapons and through tables now too (X-Pac's Super X-Factor onto a ladder or table you conveniently laid below is a bit more satisfying now, but not as much as setting up a table next to a ladder, fighting on top of the ladder, and powerbombing the guy off it in exactly the right place where you laid out the table, which you may or may not have set on fire beforehand.  But it still needs a lot of tweaking. They're clearly aiming for the more thought-provoking game we once had around 2007, with stamina and limb damage and how it affected your moves, but they're still not there yet. Even when they do add things, there's no tutorial and no real manual so people are tasked to find out themselves what icons mean or how to do things.  Another notable thing is finisher spamming and no-selling. Spamming finishers and kicking out of them has become cool. This has been replicated in the game, and it's just as ridiculous. Your matches can go 10 minutes too long because Rusev kicked out of his 10th F-5. It makes the health bars meaningless.  Unfortunately the graphics have always been a generation behind. There's been no major graphical overhaul in this version, it's still cartoony, and the Divas are still creepy as hell and have ♥♥♥♥ed up Joker smiles. Funnily enough, Steph finally looks a lot like Steph now - she seems to have a face that's been impossible to recreate in digital form thus far.  And how's the commentary? Well Cole, King and JBL are annoying as ever. They're all good guys ('faces') now, so they brown-nose everyone in the ring and spout hyperbole like how Kane and Daniel Bryan was 'one of the most famous tag teams in history'. They have conversations about the guys in the ring... then repeat THE SAME CONVERSATION a minute later. So kudos to 2K for accurately recreating their horrible, repetitive chatty commentary. Well King, if wishes were fishes...  While the roster is large (mainly because of the Austin showcase adding random guys like Savio Vega and Mikey Whipwreck), #GiveDivasAChance didn't reach WWE 2K16 so women didn't get the same treatment. Basically the only women are Trish, Lita and all the usual names. No one new like Sasha Banks, Bayley or Charlotte nor the female legends like Victoria, Molly, Ivory or dare I say Chyna. And for some reason Emma has her cool heel theme but is still dancing like an idiot and her face looks like a puffy kawaii interpretation rather than her actual self. With added sunburn to her face.  This year's Showcase has you play through an abridged version of Austin's WWE career (with a few bonus WCW and ECW matches). Haven't you done a bit of that before? Yes! You'll be replaying some of the matches you did in WWE 13's Attitude Era showcase!  There's no big extra bonus showcase this time around either, just one where you play one match each as the Hall of Fame class of 2015. Relive those historic and proud moments like when Jake the Snake beat the everloving ♥♥♥♥ out of inductee Randy Savage while Miss Elizabeth screamed for him to stop, or the time Alundra Blayze faced Paige at WrestleMania 31, or you can relive Kevin Nash's career- and industry-changing moment when he and Scott Hall... faced Harlem Heat in a tag match.  I always enjoyed Showcase mode (and it s predecessor Legends of WrestleMania), but it's not very interactive now. Here's how it goes now:  1) You start a match  2) 5-minute cutscene of entrances and opening moments of match, very slow-paced.  3) Get given an objective as you start the match (e.g. irish whip your opponent, do your finisher, throw them out the ring), this can take anything from 3 seconds to a minute or two.  4) Very slow-paced cutscene plays of what happened next in the match, this can be a few minutes, because they've got to show every second! You've now been sat here 10 minutes and only played for 2 of those minutes at most.  4b) Sometimes there's a QTE, which means you spend 20 seconds watching the buttons waiting to see which flashes, so now you're not even watching the cutscenes!  5) Go back to 3 until match is over.  This is combined with the familiar half-♥♥♥♥♥ unemotional commentary from J.R. He and King are slightly more believable, but now just sound mildly interested. I picture them sitting on the sofa, feet up in front of the TV and commentating on the match to each other.  My Career mode is where you create a guy and climb the ranks. In the last game it was just a load of meaningless matches, and it's not any different this time around. Again there's huge potential here. When I reached rank #1 for Kevin Owen's NXT title, I made sure my bosses (the game) gave me my shot by taking out Owens. He was having a match, so as he was doing his title pose during his entrance, I appeared into camera shot behind him, the crowd went mental, and I laid him out.  When I got promoted to Raw, I needed to fast track myself to the title, so I made a statement by going after the #1 contender for the world title: Brock Lesnar! He was having a match, so as he was doing his little pose during his entance, I appeared into camera shot...  Ah, you see where I'm going. That's the problem. You can go after people, make statements, do your thing, but there's only one way to do it, it's the same old ♥♥♥♥, and there's no intricate storylines. Just as in Universe Mode, two guys beat each other up each week then have a PPV match. Same every month. Even if something major happens, like joining The Authority, it's like nothing happened, just a random cutscene that played.  The unintentional highlight of this mode is the promos, delivered awfully and eerily similar to one of the Family Guy voices. 'Nothing but net.'  Every week you're very awkwardly interviewed by Renee Young. She asks you about a guy, you stare silently at each other for 10 seconds, then you get a choice of reply. A lot of the time these choices are vague, or it's a meaningless choice. You'll randomly turn heel for not trashing your bosses (The Authority) in your first month in the job as an NXT jobber, or you'll pick a harmless looking response and your guy will insult the fans or something.  There's nothing sophisticated though. All you're doing is saying if you want to feud with a guy and if you want to be heel or face. Every ♥♥♥♥ing week. Then do random matches and see random cutscenes, the same ones you've seen every month.  Universe Mode is completely unchanged. It and My Career are pretty much the same now. I've seen a lot of people say they stopped playing Career when they realised it was the same as Universe.  On its own as a game it's alright, but this is pretty much exactly the same game as last year, if not worse. I don't feel like I've wasted my time, but it's definitely wasted potential.

To keep this short and sweet, WWE 2k16 is the wrestling game that fans deserve, it is a massive improvement over 2k15 which lacked so much customization, had a lack luster career mode, terrible soundtrack and the worst matchmaking system of all time in a video game.   Pros: Game run really well, no crashes for me during my 105 Hour playthrough, and the game ran at a   constant 60FPS at 1080P (Expect for the entrances which are capped at 30FPS).    The entrances now don't have a loading screen, it just goes from one entrance to the next straight away   which adds realism to the game.   Arnold's T1 Entrance and Overall design is incredible.   Having the ability to choose what championship you want in to go after in Career Mode, as well   as choices like joining the Authority or Rebelling against them.   Soundtrack is so much better this year, and you can also use WWE Entrance Themes from the game for  Menu music as well.   Customization: You can create Divas, Arenas, Championships, Shows etc...   Stone Cold Steve Austin's Showcase Mode is just awesome.     Cons: Online matchmaking is still terrible and there is no leaderboards at all.     Renee Young's Career Interview's are repetitive, random at times with no link to your current storyline  what so ever, and she look's terrible too in the game.   No choice of Voice in Career Mode, and no Diva's Career Mode.  Overall I enjoyed WWE 2K16 way more then 2K15, If you are thinking about picking it up then you will definitely get your money's worth compared to last year, plus you get an extra 6 matches for Macho Man Randy Savage's showcase mode because you get all the game's DLC for free. 2K you are going in the right direction, keep it up.

A good PC port, if lacking in graphics options such as model, object and environment detail, but is a much better improvement over the previous game. I'm not a wrestling fan, but even I love this game, with its vast customisation, game modes, character roster and sheer amount of replay value is incredible.  Running at a locked 60 fps, WWE 2K16 sees the return of many favourite game modes, like create-an-arena, create-a-diva, match types, a whole new career mode and much more. The graphics seem better than WWE 2K15, especially with the character models and costume textures. Gameplay wise, I'm loving all the match types and going into the options menu to change rules, game hints, blood on/off and so forth. And speaking of, I also love the new mini-game-like QTEs that happen when actions like a pin, or grapple, occur. It adds a simple layer of 'fun' on-top of what is already a fun, meaty game. I love making my own movesets with my characters, making an entrance for them, and an arena for them to battle in. It's just incredibly fun and you'll be here for triple digit hours with it all!  I haven't tried online, so this is an offline review. Having said that, a couple of things I want to see added in for the inevitable sequel is better audio design. What I mean is - I want to hear the occasional character scream or grunt as they pull off certain moves; giving it immersion by proportioning realism onto what is already a realistic game. Also minor, yet near-essential things like hearing footstep noises, climbing the ladder/cages, more variety in 'punch' sounds beyond the generic slap noise. And finally, better flowing commentary: it's quite jarring hearing the commentary suddenly cut-out to talk about something else I'm doing without finishing the previous sentence.  Overall, as I said, I'm not a wrestling fan at all and I doubt this game will turn me to one, but I'm very much enjoying my time with this game. Perhaps a little more violence wouldn't hurt with enhanced persistent character damage, floors being scuffed and whatnot as per real wrestling. Having said that, this is a much better, improved, real letter to the fans that were left disappointed by the previous iteration or like me, just lost interest after so many features were dropped.  Recommend to people who enjoy sports, brawlers, RPGs, simulators and action. Worth the £35 asking price? Definitely!

TL;DR --> From an objective point of view, it isn't that good and the pricetag really doesn't justify the content it offers, even if all the DLC is free on the PC version. That being said, if you want a more in-depth analysis, please keep reading.  I've been a wrestling fan for around 10 years. I remember switching channels through my TV late in the night and finding a show that caught my interest: Smackdown! The main event that day was Bobby Lashley vs Batista vs Finlay and I won't forget that match easily.  After that, I tried my first wrestling game by renting it from a local Blockbuster (does anyone stil remember those?). It was Smackdown vs Raw 2006 for the PS2. The controls felt a little bit clunky because it tried to be something it was not: a grappling simulator. However, I enjoyed every single moment I spent on that game just because I could recreate what I saw on the show and fight with my favourite wrestlers.  Fast forward to 2016 and I'm still playing the same damn game with an updated roster and a graphic mod.  The main problem with WWE 2K16 is exactly that, they've been doing almost the same game for 10 years. Sure, they've added more game modes, characters and other stuff. They have even improved the grappling and striking system to make it more fair when playing with friends (oh the times when you had infinite reversals and they were performed just by smashing a button).  If you're a hardcore wrestling fan like me, you will probably enjoy this game, even if it has really strong weaknesses as a a PC port (fps drops, physics crashing, animations glitching...) and even if it adds nothing at all to previous WWE games but a wider roster that doesn't involve repeating the same superstar in different time periods (I'm looking at you WWE 13 and your 3-4 versions of Triple H).  However, if you're looking for a fun sports/fighting game this probably isn't the correct choice for you.

I bought the game from Humble Bundle (It's currently cheap.)    All of my play time has been me TRYING to get the game to run past the splash screen. It crashes every single time, I haven't installed any mods or even played a single match. I know my computer can handle the game as I pirated it before I bought it to see if it would play well. I've tried the fix everyone praises fixed their game, it worked one time and got me to the main menu, but I had to restart due to a scrolling issue; I haven't seen the menu since.....   Here's my suggestion:  If you really want to play the game, either buy it on console or pirate the game without the update, at least it will work that way...  EDIT: The issue was with the WIndows 10 Anniversary Update, so after a clean install of Windows 10 and a re-update to the Anniversary Update the game now launches, but will not go fullscreen without a Borderless Window app. It plays well, but I feel highly inconvinienced (I know W10 isn't officially supported, but it's still bothersome when compatibility doesn't work). So if you have Windows 10 build 1607, pass on this.  I brought the issue to 2K support, so hopefully it doesn't happen with 2K17.

WCW/NWO Revenge for the N64 is what I want in a wrestling game, this is not that type of game. I wouldn't even classify this as a game, more like a very slow, drawn out rhyhthm game. I have yet to even come close to winning a match. Here's how a typical match for me goes. Throw a punch, throw a move or two, get reversed. CPU on offense now, try to reverse, too fast, wait for CPU to finish move, try to reverse, too slow, wait for move to finish, try to reverse, too fast, wait for move to finish, try to reverse, too slow.......and so on until it comes to the submissions, oh lord the submissions are terrible. Rotate the thumbsticks to avoid your opponent, sounds easy enough. Get put in a submission, move up, it's not moving up, try to go left, WTF it went right, get submitted..you lose.   The game does look good though and I like where after the match I get interviewed by Rene Young, though I'm not sure how serious I am taken when I'm 0-20 and talking about being the greatest living legend in WWE.

I've had a bittersweet experience with this game. I first bought it directly from steam, and despite having a more than optimal hardware configuration for playing it, an error would appear every time I tried to launch the game. After trying all possible methods, I got annoyed, uninstalled it, and asked for a refund.  After almost a year, I happened to win a key for the game in a giveaway. I decided to give it a try once again, only to find the exact same error whenever I tried to launch the game. This time I decided to read the threads in the game's dicussion forum, almost one by one, until I found a solution I've not tried before (apparently it was a new solution). To my own surprise, IT WORKED! And so, I was finally able to play the game to my heart's content.  I'm really happy with this game! Sometimes the FPS drop drastically while loading some of the entrances, but besides that it works like a charm. Sure, it may take an entire minute to load at first, but it's worth it. IF the developers had not abandoned this release in order to work on the newest version, things would've been different, and users wouldn't be rating the game as badly as they're doing now. Nonetheless, if you manage to 'skip' the errors it throws at you while launching the game (the ALT+tab during Steven Austin's splash screen saves lives), you'll find it's an enjoyable experience. It has really good graphics, nice animations, a challenging AI, and an impressive roster!  So, I give this game a thumbs-up.

The submission system can either work or just spaz out sometimes. The game has very little in the way of proper introduction to some of the newer mechanics if you haven't played any recent WWE 2k games and that can really affect a match. In MyCareer mode you constantly get asked questions by a monster(mouth and eyes like to freak out) and the answers are very bland. The character creator is once again a couple steps forward and then a couple back. It takes forever for certain parts to load and sometimes they don't load until you have completely set them up. The game can still be fun if your a WWE fan, but I can't recommend it as a game. 2K has had so many chances to make a good WWE game, but it's just dissapointing that this one isn't as good as it should be. This game has major problems, knowing the history of the developer 'Yukes' you'll never see these issues go away. As bugs and glitches from 2003-2004 still persist today.  First off they are still using an Outdated 15 year old engine. The third party havok physics etc. are added on top of it. It explains why when you create a wrestler each item takes ages to load. The game has to analyze the layer of clothes etc, it's amatuer and lazy development - considering other developers like iD software's John Carmarck rewrites engines from scratch for optimization.  Much of the game does not really reflect the 'WWE' experience or pro wrestling in general. It's a step above the old arcade button mashing and going in the right direction towards sports entertainment, I'll give it that. But it cannot decide whether it wants to please Wrestling fans, Casuals or 'Multiplayer Annoying Competitive gamers who don't watch wrestling but brought this game to fight people online.' Online play is basically people running around the ring and spamming one move just to win. It's sad, the Multiplayer Non Wrestling players are pathetic. There are less Wrestling fans playing this and more Multiplayer Button Mashers have sadly brought this.  Alot of stuff hence becomes confusing to arcade gamers. Since they don't watch the show, they might not understand the significance of OMG moves etc.  Showcase mode is Cutscene + QTE-fest. It relies heavily on nostalgia for engrossment.  Yukes overlooks the best feature every year. And that is, UNIVERSE MODE. Yep, they still have no idea what to do with it, and instead spend all year focusing on Showcase mode. Universe mode now is more RPG like, but the A.I booking is trash. The realism is a joke, so much that you can call it amatuer and lazy development. Teams and stables are useless, no managers are possible in rivalries. And yeah simulate enough and your Wrestlemania main event is Darren Young vs Erick Rowan. Money in the Bank is thrown in half baked, you cannot play the match before cashing in. Custom titles have a glitch which doesn't allow the weeks to be counted. Rivalries are simply beatdowns. Stories have been removed. The personality and RPG Statpoints are so underdeveloped and pointless. 5 chairshots will make the opponent instantly get up, thats the most realismn breaking feature. In universe mode they could have added realismn, not Mortal Kombat.  Don't bother with career mode, it's a grindfest and half baked with a demonic looking Renne Young interviewing you.  Create a wrestler is slow and painful to use. Create an Arena is fine and works okay.  Create an enterance is pointless as you cannot change camera angles anymore, whats the point of having pyros if you can't allow the camera to zoom out? LAZY DEVS! Lets not forget the lack of good or usuable enterance themes. Another thing is that this game gives less custom stuff for you to use in creating shows, wrestlers etc. Transistion animations, enterances, music, titanatron are so limited. If people create stuff they don't want to use stuff that already exists.  Largest roster superficially, 1/4th of the roster are duplications of Stone Cold, Undertaker and Rock.  Lets remember, the guys who had the attention to detail in Yukes are long gone. This series is just a yearly cash grab, The graphics and engine are really showing it's age. Just see how stupid Paige, Seth Rollins etc. looks in the game.  It's sadly the only good WWE game on the store, till it's 60$ addon comes out.

2K16 is a pretty solid game that is a good gateway to understanding the appeal of professional wrestling. Not only does it cover the highlights of the poster child of WWE's Attitude Era 'Stone Cold' Steve Austin, but high points of the newest Hall of Famers like Alundra Blayze, Rikishi, and 'Macho Man' Randy Savage. Needless to say, experiencing Career Mode is a good place to start for anyone that wants to know why people tune in to buff guys pretending to hate each other (sometimes) and not-so-pretending to beat the Hell out of each other.  For those who want just a match, the roster is enormous and the modes are varied.  Wrestling is an inherently creative endeavor, and with 2K16's tools, creativity is encouraged. Build custom wrestlers with their entrances, arenas, shows, tag teams, championship belts.  Universe Mode is like being in charge of your WWE programming lineup, which means you can make something better than current programming easily.  While no means an absoultely complete and flawless experience, it's pretty close.  9/10

In not that much of a fan of the WWE, but I like wrestling games. I do recommend this game, since it's pretty good and perhaps is the best one available for PC. However, there are a few things that I don't like, I hate or I simply wished they haven't removed.  Cons -No custom matches: Which means you may only play with the ones defined by the game. Not a big variety and you can no longer change things like 'win by Finisher only' and stuff like that.  -No symetry when creating superstars or divas. You edit things with points and the lack of a symetry tool makes the process a bit tedius.  -I know it's the PG era and stuff, but I do miss the intergender matches. You can kinda 'hack' wrestlers to be able to fight intergender, but it could increase the risk of crashing the game.  -Wrestler creation process is in general slow and lacks of previews... but keep reading. XD  Pros -In depth wrestler creation. If you take your time working on this, you can get pretty awesome results. There are certain limits but in general creationg is pretty cool. Even when you can't preview anything and the process is slow, if you enjoy spending hours customizing, this game is good.  -Sharing content. Or if you're lazy and are looking for Deadpool, Rainbow Dash or Undertaker in another outfit... you can just see if someone already made it and download it.  -Universe mode. Kind of like a story mode, which can be customized. For example, you can select only your custom supersatrs to be part of the matches, set the championships and stuff. Way better than the actual story mode.  -Good gameplay. As any wrestling game lately, it takes a bit of time to get used to it, but it's pretty well done.   Long story short: If only intergender matches were a thing, as well as match creation/customization... I'd love this game. As it is now, I just think it's good.
